column26: but it should also be noted that the SDQ impact supplement was not used and therefore is not included in our analyses.Obsessive-compulsive symptoms are part of main PANS criteria but were surprisingly rare in our sample at follow-up. Assessing obsessive-compulsive symptoms with a self-rated scale as a complement to CY-BOCS may not add a lot of information within the PANS patient group at follow-up. At onset
column27: OCD is generally a more pervasive part of the symptom presentation
column28: and more time should be devoted to a comprehensive OCD assessment.We did not include a measure specifically measuring eating disorder symptoms because
column29: in our clinical experience
column30: these tend to be OCD-related and without the defining features of a typical eating disorder such as fears of gaining weight (resembling avoidant/restrictive food avoidance disorder). For selected patients with eating difficulties
column31: it may be useful to measure these symptoms in order to track their improvement.The agreement between SMFQ-P/C ratings made by parent and child was only fair
column32: indicating the importance of having both parent- and child ratings of depression and thus avoid underestimating these symptoms in PANS patients. Conversely
column33: the agreement between SAAI-P/C ratings made by parent and patient was excellent
column34: suggesting that either parent or child ratings may suffice for clinical purposes.Previous longitudinal data have shown a high comorbidity with neuropsychiatric disorders
column35: combined with intensification of related symptoms during PANS flares [5
column36: 45]. We therefore recommend measures that can screen for
column39: inattention
column40: hyperactivity and conduct problems when following up PANS. In our sample ECBI had a very strong association to SNAP-IV
column41: suggesting that the simpler SNAP-IV may sufficiently cover the patients’ oppositional behaviors for clinical purposes. When detecting potentially severe oppositional defiant behaviors
column42: ECBI can be used as a complement.Our study has some limitations. First
column43: we analyzed data from a small sample of patients from a single clinic. Second
column44: the age range was such that the results of the child-rated measures should be interpreted with caution; despite our efforts
column45: it is possible that the younger children received help from their parents to fill in their questionnaires. Third
column46: we were not able to calculate internal consistency of the scales included in this study (only total scores were available). We could thus not examine the psychometric properties of the scales in this particular sample. Future studies would benefit from conducting such psychometric analyses.SummaryClinical experience and the results from our follow-up study suggest that it is important to include clinician-
column47: parent- and child ratings in the assessment of PANS
column48: as a single perspective is unlikely to capture the full complexity of the syndrome. Brief
column49: general measures assessing global disease severity and adaptive functioning
column50: are clinically helpful and should be used but should be complemented by symptom-specific scales representative of the core symptoms in PANS
column51: such as OCD
column52: anxiety
column53: depression and behavioral problems. However
column54: their exclusive use is problematic as the natural course of the syndrome is such that some patients may not have specific symptoms to rate at follow-up. Furthermore
column55: it is important that the assessment is straightforward and as brief as possible. Based on our experience
column56: we recommend the use of a core battery of clinician-
column57: parent- and child-rated measures in both clinical practice and in clinical trials (Table 7). The proposed core battery of measures will provide a broad evaluation of PANS-related symptoms
column58: but can be complemented with further symptom-specific measures when needed.

column95: provided the original work is properly cited.Neuroimmunology in the broadest sense is the study of interactions between the nervous and the immune systems. These interactions play important roles in health from supporting neural development
column96: homeostasis and plasticity to modifying behaviour. Neuroimmunology is increasingly recognised as a field with the potential to deliver a significant positive impact on human health and treatment for neurological and psychiatric disorders. Yet
column97: translation to the clinic is hindered by fundamental knowledge gaps on the underlying mechanisms of action or the optimal timing of an intervention
column98: and a lack of appropriate tools to visualise and modulate both systems. Here we propose ten key disease-agnostic research questions that
column99: if addressed
column100: could lead to significant progress within neuroimmunology in the short to medium term. We also discuss four cross-cutting themes to be considered when addressing each question: i) bi-directionality of neuroimmune interactions; ii) the biological context in which the questions are addressed (e.g. health vs disease vs across the lifespan); iii) tools and technologies required to fully answer the questions; and iv) translation into the clinic. We acknowledge that these ten questions cannot represent the full breadth of gaps in our understanding; rather they focus on areas which
column101: if addressed
column102: may have the most broad and immediate impacts. By defining these neuroimmunology priorities
column103: we hope to unite existing and future research teams
column104: who can make meaningful progress through a collaborative and cross-disciplinary effort.Peripheral nervous systemcentral nervous systempsychoneuroimmunologyimmunopsychiatrybehaviourmental healthinflammationneuroimmune interactionsWellcome StaffNo funding directly supported this work. column1: 7.Identifying the research priorities in neuroimmunologySetting research priorities requires bringing together the relevant stakeholders to collectively determine which ‘uncertainties’ in a field are the most pressing issues to resolve through research. Identifying the key scientific questions can help a community galvanise around a common set of goals and facilitate the formation of new collaborations.To accomplish this

column10: provided the original work is properly cited.Version 1recommendationapproveThere is a lack of visibility of neuroimmunology in both the medical literature and its translation into clinical practice. Seventeen very well-respected scientists from the United Kingdom came together to address these and other issues. They lay the groundwork for a path forward to move biomedical research on communication systems between the central nervous and immune systems into the clinic. The authors do a good job of acknowledging and documenting the progress in basic research made in this field during the past few decades. Nevertheless
column11: there is a real need to further support this rapidly expanding field by trying to understand reciprocal systems of communication that are now known to exist between the immune system and brain. column2: it is curious that the noun “physiology” is never mentioned throughout the entire paper. Yet systemic physiology is based not only on structure and function but also on communication systems among various organs in the body. Lungs communicate with the brain to regulate blood gas levels and the heart communicates with the lungs for the same reason. The kidney and lungs communicate with one another to maintain acid-base balance. These systems form regulatory feedback loops
column3: which control everything from reproductive cycles to stress responses. It seems that

column46: unless otherwise stated in a credit line to the data.BackgroundCancer patients experience increased risk of death from accident and suicide. Cognitive impairment induced by cancer-related inflammation and stress-related psychiatric symptoms may be underlying mechanisms. We therefore studied the association between use of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) and risk of these outcomes.MethodsFollowing a cohort of 388
column47: 443 cancer patients diagnosed between October 2005 and December 2014 in Sweden
column48: we ascertained dispense of aspirin or non-aspirin NSAIDs from 3 months before cancer diagnosis onward and defined the on-medication period as from date of drug dispense until the prescribed dosage was consumed. Follow-up time outside medicated periods and time from unexposed patients were defined as off-medication periods. We used Cox models to estimate hazard ratios (HRs) of death due to suicide or accident
column49: by comparing the on-medication periods with off-medication periods.ResultsIn total
column50: 29.7% of the cancer patients had low-dose aspirin dispensed and 29.1% had non-aspirin NSAIDs dispensed. Patients with aspirin use were more likely to be male than patients without aspirin use. Compared with off-medication periods
column51: there was a 22% lower risk of accidental death (N = 651; HR 0.78

column476: and calendar year of cancer diagnosis. Time since cancer diagnosis was used as the underlying timescaleDiscussionUsing a nationwide cohort study
column477: we assessed the association between use of low-dose aspirin and non-aspirin NSAIDs and the risk of unnatural deaths among cancer patients. We found that low-dose aspirin use was associated with a 22% lower risk of death due to accident but not suicide whereas use of non-aspirin NSAIDs was not associated with the risk of either death due to accident or suicide. When separately analyzing prevalent use and incident use
column478: we found that prevalent use of either aspirin or non-aspirin NSAIDs was associated with a lower risk of death due to accident
column479: whereas incident use of such medication was not. Our study provides evidence for a potentially beneficial effect of NSAID use
column480: especially low-dose aspirin and long-term use
column481: in reducing severe accidents after cancer diagnosis.Strength and limitationsThe major strength of this study includes the nationwide population-based cohort design
column483: and the prospectively and independently collected information on medication
column486: which largely minimized the potential risk of selection and information biases. The use of dispensed rather than prescribed medications
column487: the use of prescription text to define medication status
column488: and the time-varying definition of medication use served to limit potential misclassification of the exposure. Because medications are largely financed by the universal healthcare insurance to each resident in Sweden
column489: the findings of the present study are not likely greatly influenced by other factors such as socioeconomic status.One limitation of the study is that the Prescribed Drug Register does not include medications administered during hospitalization or in nursing home. This may result in misclassification of the exposure to some extent. However
column490: it is unlikely that such misclassification is differential in terms of the outcomes. Another limitation is that we did not have information on the actual consumption of medications among patients defined as exposed to these medications according to drug dispense. In our study
column491: 84.0% patients ever medicated with low-dose aspirin had at least two dispensing records
column492: indicating that vast majority of the users of low-dose aspirin had likely consumed the dispensed medications. Further
column493: because patients who did not consume medications as expected should ideally have contributed their person time to the off-medication periods rather than on-medication periods
column494: this misclassification is expected to have led to underestimation of the inverse association noted for aspirin use. Because information on other potential confounders such as lifestyle factors was unavailable
column495: and there was a proportion of cancer patients with unknown cancer stage
column496: residual confounding remains a concern. The similar results obtained in the within-individual comparison and after multiple imputation for unknown cancer stage alleviated this concern to some extent. There is also a concern of indication bias
column497: namely that the indications for NSAIDs use - mostly inflammatory conditions - might have biased the estimates of the studied associations. This is likely most relevant for first-time use of aspirin and non-aspirin NSAIDs
column498: for both of which an increased risk of death due to incidents was noted. As a result
column499: the overall association as reported in Table 2 could also have been biased partially due to this. Finally
column500: the possibility of chance findings cannot be excluded completely because of the smaller number of outcomes
column501: and this is especially true for completed suicide.Interpretation of resultsThe excess risks of suicide and accidents among cancer patients have been reported in many countries [4
column504: 33]. Although more than twice as many cancer patients die from accidents than from suicide [6
column506: risk of death due to accident and its underlying reasons has been less investigated. Psychological distress related to receiving a cancer diagnosis and treatment
column507: together with its resultant psychiatric symptoms such as depression
column509: may trigger the occurrence of both suicide and accidents in cancer patients [7
column511: potential preventive strategies have not been developed to mitigate the elevated risk of these outcomes. In our study
column512: we found that low-dose aspirin use was associated with a lower risk of death due to accident. This finding
column514: supports a potential role of aspirin use in reducing stress-related outcomes due to its anti-inflammatory properties [35
column516: both cognitive impairment and peripheral neuropathy have been associated with inflammation in cancer patients
column517: which was further correlated with deficits in motor function [37
column519: 40]. Aspirin may intervene in this process and modify the risk. Although not statistically significant
column520: it seems the lowest estimate on risk reduction was observed among patients with severe cancers (cancer in esophagus
column521: liver or pancreas). It is possible that this group of patients can potentially benefit more from the anti-inflammatory property of aspirin due to their high level of either tumor-induced or treatment-associated inflammation [41
column522: 42].The lack of statistically significant association between low-dose aspirin and risk of death due to suicide may indicate indeed a lack of association. However
column523: it is also possible that an underlying association is masked by methodological issues. This contention is in particular compelling given recent findings showing that aspirin use reduces the risk of depression [21]
column524: which is a major predictor of suicide [7]. Unlike unpredictable death due to accident
column525: completed suicide is intentional. During the immediate time period before suicide
column526: patients might stop taking or dispensing medications [43]. This could have led to different kinds of biases. For instance
column527: if the patients had dispensed aspirin recently
column528: they would be counted as exposed to aspirin despite not actually using it. Alternatively
column530: patients might be less likely to dispense prescribed medications
column531: leading to an artificial protective effect
column533: less patients would have dispensed aspirin during the time before suicide compared to expected. Another possible explanation for the lack of a statistically significant association is the lack of statistical power because of the smaller number of completed suicide. Moreover
column534: suicide is known to be a challenge in classifying causes of death
column535: and can be misclassified as deaths due to accident [44]. When combining completed suicide and deaths due to accident as one outcome
column536: we found a 21% lower risk of unnatural deaths associated with the use of low-dose aspirin. A protective effect of low-dose aspirin on the risk of suicide following a cancer diagnosis can therefore not be ruled out.Prevalent use of non-aspirin NSAIDs
column538: was found to be associated with a lower risk of accidental death. Non-aspirin NSAIDs are a class of drugs with analgesic
column540: and anti-pyretic therapeutic properties [45]. Because of their side effect on gastrointestinal and cardiovascular systems when used chronically [46
column542: non-aspirin NSAIDs are recommended for use at the lowest effective dose
column543: and for short-term use when possible [48]. In our study
column544: the average duration of exposure to non-aspirin NSAIDs (1.4 months
column545: corresponding to 4% of exposed follow-up time) was substantially shorter compared with the average duration of exposure to low-dose aspirin (16 months
column546: corresponding to 77% of exposed follow-up time). This is also reflected by the greater numbers of outcomes among on-medication periods with aspirin compared to the on-medication periods with non-aspirin NSAIDs (see Table 2 for instance). As a result
column547: the null overall association between non-aspirin NSAIDs and risk of death due to accident might be due to chance (or lack of statistical power). In a sensitivity analysis
column548: we observed an inverse association between prevalent use of both aspirin and non-aspirin NSAIDs
column549: but not incident use of either
column550: and risk of death due to accident. These results suggest that long-term use of NSAIDs
column552: is likely to be associated with a lower risk of death due to accident among cancer patients. The overall null association between non-aspirin NSAIDs and risk of death due to accident might therefore be attributable to the fact that most of the non-aspirin NSAIDs are used in short term whereas short-term use of such medication is unlikely to be associated with a lower risk of death due to accident among cancer patients. column39: Australia. a.walker@neura.edu.au0822022520220822022211004282192021722022722022© 2022 The Authors2022https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/This is an open access article under the CC BY-NC-ND license (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/).Disruption of circadian rhythms occurs in rotating shift-work
column40: jetlag
column41: and in individuals with irregular sleep schedules. Circadian disruption is known to alter inflammatory responses and impair immune function. However
column42: there is limited understanding of how circadian disruption modulates cancer-induced inflammation. Inflammation is a hallmark of cancer and is linked to worse prognosis and impaired brain function in cancer patients. Here
column43: we investigated the effect of circadian disruption on cancer-induced inflammation in an orthotopic breast cancer model. Using a validated chronic jetlag protocol that advances the light-cycle by 8 ​h every 2 days to disrupt circadian rhythms
column44: we found that circadian disruption alters cancer-induced inflammation in a tissue-specific manner
column45: increasing inflammation in the body and brain while decreasing inflammation within the tumor tissue. Circadian disruption did not affect inflammation in mice without tumors
column46: suggesting that the impact of circadian disruption may be particularly detrimental in the context of underlying inflammatory conditions
column47: such as cancer. Importantly
column48: circadian disruption did not affect tumor burden
column49: suggesting that increased inflammation was not a result of increased cancer progression. Overall
column50: these findings identify the importance of healthy circadian rhythms for limiting cancer-induced inflammation.Highlights•Circadian disruption enhances cancer-induced inflammation in the body and brain.•The profile of inflammatory cytokines altered by circadian disruption is tissue specific.•Changes in inflammatory profiles by circadian ​disruption are not due to enhanced tumor burden.KeywordsChronic jetlag4T1 breast CancerCytokinesNeuroinflammationMetastasisClock genesCircadian rhythms1IntroductionDisruption of circadian rhythms affects the immune system and alters inflammatory responses (Cuesta et al.
column51: 2016). Circadian rhythms are endogenously generated cycles that regulate many physiological processes
column52: including metabolism
column53: cellular proliferation
column54: immune function
column55: and neurocognitive function (Baxter and Ray
column56: 2020). In mammals
column57: the suprachiasmatic nucleus of the hypothalamus is the body's master circadian clock
column58: which synchronizes and aligns circadian rhythms throughout the body in response to environmental light/dark patterns (Weaver
column59: 1998). Disruption to light/dark patterns can cause disruption of circadian rhythms (Vetter
column60: 2020). Shift-work
column61: trans-meridian flights (jetlag)
column62: and pervasive exposure to artificial light at night are all known to disrupt circadian rhythms (Cain et al.
column63: 2020; Pilorz et al.
column64: 2018).The importance of robust circadian rhythms for health and well-being is now accepted (Allada and Bass
column66: and disruption of circadian clocks is associated with many chronic health issues including cancer. Epidemiological studies have demonstrated increased cancer rates in populations susceptible to circadian disruption like shift workers (Fagundo-Rivera et al.
column69: and circadian rhythm disruption has been shown to influence efficacy and toxicity of cancer treatments like chemotherapy in patients (Hrushesky
column71: 1996). Preclinical cancer models support these findings with evidence that circadian disruption enhances cancer progression (Aiello et al.
column73: impairs anti-cancer immunity (Hadadi et al.
column75: and promotes tumor resistance to chemotherapy (Xiang et al.
column77: 2019). One key mechanism linking the circadian system and cancer is inflammation (Sulli et al.
column79: which is likely bidirectional. Inflammation has been demonstrated to disrupt circadian rhythms and blunt clock gene expression (Guo et al.
column80: 2015; Xiong et al.
column81: 2019). On the other hand
column82: disruption of circadian rhythms affects the immune system and alters inflammatory responses (Cuesta et al.
column83: 2016). Moreover
column84: cancer itself has been shown to flatten circadian rhythms in Ly6cHi (proinflammatory) monocytes in a mouse model of breast cancer (Sullivan et al.
column85: 2019).Inflammation is a hallmark of cancer (Hanahan and Weinberg
column86: 2011) that promotes cancer progression (Deshmukh et al.
column88: and is associated with poor prognosis (Diakos et al.
column90: reduced treatment efficacy (Slaviero et al.
column92: and cancer-related morbidities including fatigue and cognitive and affective dysfunction (Lacourt et al.
column93: 2018; Pyter et al.
column94: 2009; Walker et al.
column95: 2018). Inflammatory cytokines can be produced by tumor cells (Walker et al.
column96: 2018) or tumor-associated stromal cells (Solinas et al.
column98: and once in circulation can have detrimental systemic effects (Diakos et al.
column99: 2014). Cancer-induced inflammation can also promote the synthesis of pro-inflammatory mediators in organs distant to the tumor site
column100: including the brain (Santos et al.
column101: 2019). Treatment with the anti-inflammatory drug aspirin reduces long-term mortality from cancer (Rothwell et al.
column102: 2011) and reduces distant metastasis (Rothwell et al.
column104: demonstrating that inflammation can directly affect long-term outcomes in clinical populations. While it has been shown in non-cancer settings that circadian disruption dysregulates inflammatory responses (Baxter and Ray
column105: 2020) and is linked to cognitive and affective dysfunction (Karatsoreos et al.
column106: 2011; Otsuka et al.
column108: it is not known whether circadian disruption modulates cancer-induced inflammation.Here
column109: we implanted mammary carcinoma cells into mice with established circadian disruption to determine how circadian disruption affects cancer-induced inflammation. Using a validated chronic jetlag protocol to disrupt circadian rhythms we investigated changes in cancer-associated inflammatory gene expression in distinct sites of the body and brain - the hypothalamus which houses the master clock (suprachiasmatic nucleus)
column110: the liver which is anatomically and functionally distinct from the orthotopic tumor site (mammary fatpad) and known to be sensitive to circadian disruption (Ferrell and Chiang
column112: and the tumor itself. We also explored whether altered inflammation was associated with changes in primary tumor growth
column113: metastasis
column114: memory impairment
column115: and depression-like behavior. We chose to explore the impact of circadian disruption using 4T1.2 mammary tumor-induced inflammation because the link between breast cancer and circadian rhythms is well established in the clinic and in preclinical studies (Fagundo-Rivera et al.
column116: 2020; Sullivan et al.
column118: and we have previously characterized the effect of mammary tumors on memory and sickness behavior using this model (Walker et al.
column119: 2018). The findings demonstrate that circadian disruption enhanced the inflammatory profile induced by cancer
column120: which may have important implications for survival outcomes and quality of life for cancer patients exposed to environmental factors that disrupt circadian rhythms.2Methods2.1Animals and ethics80 BALB/c female mice (8–12 weeks old) (Monash University

column162: based on a predictive processing framework.Hierarchical Predictive Processing – A neurobiologically plausible theory of the brainUnder conceptualisations of predictive processing
column163: the brain is formalised as a statistical organ that continuously seeks to render the external environment predictable. This is achieved through forming and testing predictions of generative models (i.e.
column164: models that explain how sensory inputs are generated probabilistically by latent states of the world) against incoming sensory evidence (Clark
column165: 2013). By inverting generative models (i.e.
column166: computing the probability of the states of the world
column167: given the sensory inputs)
column168: perception is described as a form of statistical inference achieved through minimizing the discrepancy (prediction error) between predictions (or perceptual hypotheses) and current sensory evidence (Stephan et al.
column169: 2016). Unlike traditional views of perception as a stimulus-response process
column170: perception is instead highly ingrained and contextualised by our beliefs2 about the statistical nature of the world (Clark
column171: 2015). In keeping with the Bayesian brain hypothesis (Knill & Pouget
column173: models are cast as following an approximate form of Bayesian inference. This inferential process is implemented through predictive coding (Friston
column174: 2005; Rao & Ballard
column175: 1999). Together
column176: multilevel cortical systems are proposed to transfer prediction and prediction error across a series of recurrent ‘loops
column177: ’ in which probabilistic predictions (or priors/beliefs) are passed top-down from higher to lower levels
column178: while prediction errors (i.e.
column179: the unexplained data) travel laterally (within the same level) and ascend through forward projections to the level above and serve to update predictions (Fig. 1). This is equivalent to a belief update or the transformation of prior into posterior probabilities. In these models
column180: the goal is to update beliefs at all levels of the hierarchy such that the discrepancy between predicted states and sensory inputs is minimal. Optimization of posterior probability therefore operates through the minimization of prediction error and enables perceptual inference

column22: autoimmune mechanisms underlying schizophrenia are suspected; however

column32: anti-NCAM1 autoantibodies in patients with schizophrenia cause schizophrenia-related behavior and changes in synapses in mice. These antibodies may be a potential therapeutic target and serve as a biomarker to distinguish a small but treatable subgroup in heterogeneous patients with schizophrenia.Graphical abstractHighlights•Some patients with schizophrenia are positive for anti-NCAM1 autoantibodies•Anti-NCAM1 antibody from schizophrenia patients inhibits NCAM1-NCAM1 interactions•Anti-NCAM1 antibody from schizophrenia patients reduces spines and synapses in mice•Anti-NCAM1 antibody from patients induces schizophrenia-related behavior in miceShiwaku et al. show that autoantibodies against NCAM1 from schizophrenia patients cause schizophrenia-related behavior and changes in spines and synapses in mice. These autoantibodies may cause symptoms of schizophrenia and can therefore be regarded as a therapeutic target for patients who are positive for anti-NCAM1 autoantibodies.KeywordsschizophreniaNCAM1anti-NCAM1 autoantibodyimmunopsychiatryPublished: April 19
column33: 2022IntroductionPatients with schizophrenia are symptomatically and genetically heterogeneous
column34: and it is assumed that there are various underlying pathological mechanisms.1 However
column35: there are no biomarkers for these heterozygous subgroups
column36: and elucidation of pathological mechanisms underlying treatment resistance in patients and/or symptoms is insufficient.Genetic analysis of schizophrenia has revealed risk genes related to synapse
column40: 4 In particular
column41: mutations in the major histocompatibility complex (MHC) region carry the highest risk of schizophrenia.2 The MHC region also plays a role in autoimmunity. In fact
column42: there is an epidemiological relationship between schizophrenia and autoimmunity;5 however
column43: the role of autoimmune responses in schizophrenia remains unclear.Autoantibodies are a primary driver of autoimmunity. Indeed
column44: autoantibodies specific for synaptic membrane molecules have been found in patients with encephalitis.6
column45: 7 Some autoantibodies specific for these molecules cause psychotic symptoms in those with encephalitis. One of the most extensively studied autoantibody-mediated forms of encephalitis is anti-N-methyl-d-aspartate (NMDA) receptor antibody encephalitis
column46: which is associated with schizophrenia-related symptoms.8 In addition
column47: anti-GABAARα1 receptor antibody encephalitis causes psychotic symptoms.9 Although these autoantibodies are also present in patients with schizophrenia
column48: it is unclear whether they play a role in the symptoms of schizophrenia.10
column49: 11When searching for autoantibodies related to the pathology of schizophrenia
column50: there are several prerequisites: the target antigen must be (1) a membrane molecule expressed in the nervous system (autoantibodies do not usually enter cells in vivo) and (2) a molecule implicated in schizophrenia and whose function would be affected by autoantibodies or at least be involved in synaptic function. From this point of view
column51: we used a cell-based assay and ELISA to identify novel autoantibodies that may contribute to schizophrenia pathophysiology. One candidate antigen was neural cell adhesion molecule (NCAM1)
column52: a synaptic adhesion molecule that supports synaptic connections by trans-homophilic binding.12 NCAM1 also binds to glial-cell-line-derived neurotrophic factor (GDNF) and contributes to synapse formation.12
column53: 13 Various studies have been conducted on NCAM1 and schizophrenia; changes in mRNA expression levels and the cleaved soluble form of NCAM1 are associated with schizophrenia.14
column59: NCAM1 knockout and transgenic mice with a dominant-negative form of NCAM1 show schizophrenia-related behavioral changes.20
column62: 23 Furthermore
column63: single-nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) of NCAM1 are associated with schizophrenia.24
column65: 26In this study
column66: we identified anti-NCAM1 autoantibodies in some patients with schizophrenia. Using a disease model in which mice were administered immunoglobulin G (IgG) purified from patients with schizophrenia
column67: we show that anti-NCAM1 autoantibodies inhibit spine and synapse formation in the frontal cortex and induce schizophrenia-related behavior.ResultsIdentification of anti-NCAM1 autoantibodies in patients with schizophreniaSerum samples were obtained from 201 healthy controls (125 males and 76 females; age
column68: 22–90 years; median
column69: 48 years) and 223 patients with schizophrenia (112 males and 111 females; age
column71: 52 years). Schizophrenia was diagnosed according to the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-5). There were no significant differences between the groups with respect to age. All samples were tested using the ELISA and the cell-based assay. The ELISA analysis detected 15 patients with schizophrenia as positive for anti-NCAM1 autoantibodies
column72: where two standard deviations above the mean of absorbance was defined as positive for this autoantibody (Figure 1A). None of the healthy control subjects was positive for anti-NCAM1 autoantibodies in the ELISA. The antibody titers of patients with schizophrenia were significantly high compared with those in healthy controls (Figure 1A). In the cell-based assay using HeLa cells
column73: human NCAM1 and EGFP were expressed from a plasmid
column74: and all transfected cells expressing EGFP showed exogenous expression of NCAM1 (Figures 1B and S1A). Twelve patients with schizophrenia (5.4%) were positive for anti-NCAM1 autoantibodies (Figures 1B
column75: 1C
column76: and S1B; Table 1). To test whether these patients also have other autoantibodies against other synaptic molecules
column77: we induced the expression of NLGN1

column304: we identified anti-NCAM1 autoantibodies in patients with schizophrenia. Administration of IgG antibodies isolated from patients with schizophrenia interrupted NCAM1-NCAM1 and NCAM1-GDNF interactions. These interruptions affect the NCAM1-Fyn-FAK-MEK1-ERK1 signaling pathway and inhibited NCAM1-Fyn interactions as well as the phosphorylation of FAK

column308: which is an established endophenotype of schizophrenia in humans and mice.41

column312: such as the 22q11.2 deletion syndrome mouse model
column316: 46 A reduction in the number of spines and synapses has also been reported in patients with schizophrenia as well as mice models of schizophrenia.47
column319: 50These behavioral and synaptic changes are also found in NCAM1 KO mice and transgenic mice with a dominant negative form of NCAM1.20

column325: 26 The reports that SNPs of NCAM1 or the expression level of soluble NCAM1 are associated with cognitive impairment of patients with schizophrenia may relate to our analysis of cognitive impairment in mice administered with anti-NCAM1 autoantibodies from patients with schizophrenia.16

column356: this does not entirely dismiss the existence of other autoantibodies. Therefore
column357: future experiments with highly purified anti-NCAM1 autoantibodies from patients with schizophrenia would be ideal to reveal the specific effect of this autoantibody. column418: such as cancer or autoimmune disease. Analysis of the MHC gene region may be one possible approach to clarifying the mechanism underlying generation of anti-NCAM1 antibodies.In conclusion
column419: we identified anti-NCAM1 antibodies in a small subgroup of patients with schizophrenia. These antibodies cause schizophrenia-related behavior and changes in synapses in mice. column423: which better reflects the case of schizophrenia
